elements.content: The self-assembly of macrocyclic tetranuclear 3d–4f single-molecule magnet (SMM) building blocks, [CuII 3TbIII(L Pr )­(NO3)2(H2O)]­NO3 (1), with K3[MIII(CN)6] linkers, where M = Fe, Cr, or Co, results in a range of discrete (monomer and dimer) and one-dimensional (1D) chain (coordination polymer) supramolecular architectures, which have been structurally and magnetically characterized. The outcome of reactions of 1 with an excess of K3[Fe­(CN)6] has been probed in detail. It was found to be dependent on several factors, resulting in five distinctly different compounds, all of which have the same 1:1 ratio of [Cu3Tb­(L Pr )]3+ to [Fe­(CN)6]3–, but which differ in structural type, solvent content, and magnetic behavior. Three are discrete complexes: monomeric {[Cu3Tb­(L Pr )­(H2O)5]­[Fe­(CN)6]·(H2O)3·(MeCN)]} (2) and [Cu3Tb­(L Pr )­Fe­(CN)6(H2O)4(MeCN)]·(H2O)2·(MeCN) (3) plus dimeric {[Cu3Tb­(L Pr )­Fe­(CN)6(H2O)4]·(H2O)6.75}2 (4), while two are 1D chains (coordination polymers): {[Cu3Tb­(L Pr )cis-Fe­(CN)6(H2O)3(MeOH)]·(H2O)3.75·(MeOH)0.75} n (5) and {[Cu3Tb­(L Pr )trans-Fe­(CN)6(H2O)4]·(H2O)5·(DMF)5]} n (6). When K3[Cr­(CN)6] or K3[Co­(CN)6] are used in place of K3[Fe­(CN)6], a discrete dimer {[Cu3Tb­(L Pr )­Cr­(CN)6(H2O)4]·(H2O)2.75}2 (7) and a 1D chain coordination polymer {[Cu3Tb­(L Pr )­Co­(CN)6(H2O)3(MeOH)]·(H2O)4·(MeOH)} n (8) are obtained, respectively, which are isomorphous with 4 and 5, respectively. Magnetic studies reveal the paramagnetism of these compounds down to 1.8 K, except for 7, which displays an ordered antiferromagnetic ground state with metamagnetic behavior. The 1D-coordination polymers (5, 6, and 8) do not exhibit single-chain magnet properties, because of the very weak interbuilding block magnetic interactions. For chain 8, below 2.8 K, a clear nonzero out-of-phase signal is seen, similar to that seen for the building block 1, so the magnetism of 8 is governed by that of these SMM building blocks (1).

When K3[Cr(CN)6] or K3[Co(CN)6] are used in place of K3[Fe(CN)6], a discrete dimer {[Cu3Tb(L  Pr )Cr(CN)6(H2O)4]⋅(H2O)2.75}2 (7) and a 1D chain coordination polymer {[Cu3Tb(L  Pr )Co(CN)6(H2O)3(MeOH)]⋅(H2O)4⋅(MeOH)} n  (8) are obtained, respectively, which are isomorphous with 4 and 5, respectively. elements.content: The outcome of assembling macrocyclic single-molecule magnet building blocks, [CuII 3TbIII(L Pr )]3+, with [MIII(CN)6]3+ linkers (M = Fe, Cr, or Co) is dependent on the conditions employed and includes seven structurally and magnetically characterized discrete monomer and dimer complexes plus 1D chain (one-dimensional coordination polymer) supramolecular architectures.

elements.content: Single-chain magnets (SCMs) are materials composed of one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymers with negligible interchain magnetic interactions that show slow relaxation of magnetization because of intrachain magnetic interactions and the intrinsic magnetic anisotropy of the chain repeating units. As such, they are of interest for nanoscale data storage and quantum computing. Since the discovery of the first 1D coordination polymer displaying slow dynamics of the magnetization in 2001, numerous SCMs are now known, with a record blocking temperature of ∼13 K. Although this is somewhat lower than the recent records of 60 K and 80 K observed for the analogous zero-dimension systems known as single-molecule magnets (SMMs), SCMs have shown coercive fields larger than record values for commercial magnets.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Single-chain magnets (SCMs) are materials composed of one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymers with negligible interchain magnetic interactions that show slow relaxation of magnetization because of intrachain magnetic interactions and the intrinsic magnetic anisotropy of the chain repeating units. As such, they are of interest for nanoscale data storage and quantum computing. Since the discovery of the first 1D coordination polymer displaying slow dynamics of the magnetization in 2001, numerous SCMs are now known, with a record blocking temperature of ~13 K. Although this is somewhat lower than the recent records of 60 K and 80 K observed for the analogous zero-dimension systems known as single-molecule magnets (SMMs), SCMs have shown coercive fields larger than record values for commercial magnets.

elements.content: The original dynamics of the magnetization in 1D Ising systems were first predicted by Glauber in 1963. Two main conditions must be fulfilled in order to observe SCM behavior. The first is the presence of an Ising-like, i.e., uniaxial, magnetic anisotropy along the chain; the second is that interchain interactions in the crystal are negligible, compared to the intrachain coupling. The first requirement is challenging but is met by the use of appropriate transition-metal ions such as Co­(II) or Mn­(III), or by lanthanide ions such as Tb­(III), and placing them in environments of appropriate structure and symmetry to ensure the individual uniaxial anisotropy axes line up along the chain. The second requirement is met by using diamagnetic spacers or bulky organic ligands to separate the chains. A variety of strategies has been used to synthesize SCMs, including the synthesis of chains from SMM building blocks. It is also pertinent to the present work to note that only a handful of SCMs have been synthesized from macrocyclic complexes.

elements.content: Macrocycles give the chemist considerable control over the environment of the incorporated metal ion(s). We have focused on generating families of 3d–4f complexes of large tetranucleating Schiff-base macrocycles (), related to systems developed by Nabeshima and co-workers and by MacLachlan and co-workers. These macrocycles selectively bind three transition-metal ions and one lanthanide metal ion in four carefully designed binding pockets, 3 × N2O2 and 1 × O6 respectively, within the macrocyclic cavity. The particular focus of our studies was placed on generating 3d–4f SMMs that are tetrametallic by design, stabilized and solubilized by the organic macrocyclic ring, and can be fine-tuned (by choice of 3d or 4f ion or by modifying the macrocyclic ring) while retaining the tetrametallic 3d–4f structural motif. We generated the first such macrocyclic SMM, while Nabeshima and co-workers almost simultaneously reported the second one. Subsequently, we have gone on to establish that our macrocyclic approach robustly gives tetrametallic 3d–4f [M3Ln­(L R )] complexes, the magnetic properties of which can be tuned by choice of M, Ln, or L R ().

elements.content: Family of 3d–4f tetrametallic Schiff-base macrocyclic complexes [M3Ln­(L R )]3+ (R = Et, Pr, or Bu). The present study concerns the wide variety of architectures obtained from self-assembly of one of these complexes, [Cu3Tb­(L Pr )­(NO3)2(H2O)]­NO3 (1), with hexacyanometallates (see Figures and ).

elements.content: Here, the tetranuclear macrocyclic complex [Cu3Tb­(L Pr )­(NO3)2(H2O)]­NO3 (1), that we have previously shown to be an SMM, is employed as a building block for the assembly of larger supramolecular architectures, aiming in particular for chains that might show SCM properties. These architectures can be formed via coordination of linker molecules to the apical positions of the 3d and/or 4f metal ions in these tetranuclear macrocyclic complexes. We have reported a proof-of-principle study in which the [Cu3Tb­(L Pr )]3+ moieties of 1 were linked together via octacyanometallate [WV(CN)8]3–, anions which bridge the axial sites of two different copper­(II) centers of each macrocycle, resulting in stepped and square-wave chains. In the present study, we employ hexacyanometallate linkers, [MIII(CN)6]3–, where M = Fe, Cr, or Co, to bridge the macrocyclic SMM building blocks (). Such a strategy of attempting to prepare an SCM by linking SMMs has been used by several groups.

These architectures can be formed via coordination of linker molecules to the apical positions of the 3d and/or 4f metal ions in these tetranuclear macrocyclic complexes. We have reported a proof-of-principle study in which the [Cu3Tb(L  Pr )]3+ moieties of 1 were linked together via octacyanometallate [WV(CN)8]3-, anions which bridge the axial sites of two different copper(II) centers of each macrocycle, resulting in stepped and square-wave chains. In the present study, we employ hexacyanometallate linkers, [MIII(CN)6]3-, where M = Fe, Cr, or Co, to bridge the macrocyclic SMM building blocks (). Such a strategy of attempting to prepare an SCM by linking SMMs has been used by several groups.

elements.content: As with the octacyanometallate linker used previously, these hexacyanometallate linkers were selected because they are trianions, so they will perfectly balance the charge of the tricationic SMM building block, [Cu3Tb­(L Pr )]3+, promoting the formation of 1:1 systems. Cyanide bridges have been shown to be efficient coordinating linkers that also mediate significant exchange interactions between paramagnetic centers, and so have been widely used in SCM synthesis. Considering the most relevant examples to this studyi.e., those containing a CuII ion in the N2O2 pocket of a salen-type ligand bridged to either a CuII or LnIII ion via a [MIII(CN) x ](3–x) moietya search of the CSD (version 5.39) reveals that there are 31 structurally characterized examples (see , as well as Tables S1–S3 in the Supporting Information). Note that, if all types of ligands (not just salen derivatives) are considered, then the number of examples featuring a Cu–NC–M (M = Cr, Fe, Co) is large, with 355 complexes reported in the CSD (version 5.39). Of the 31 closely related complexes described above, two-thirds of them (23 complexes) feature M = Fe. Just 9 examples are 1D chains (coordination polymers), with M = Cr (1 example), Fe (6 examples), or Co (2 examples). The other 22 examples are discrete systems, with M = Cr (4 examples), Fe (17 examples), or Co (1 example). Two of the 9 examples of chains display SCM behavior. Both are trans-1D-chains (type 4 in ) of 3d–4f salen-type complexes that feature [FeIII(CN)6]3– linkers between (i) the CuII and TbIII ions of adjacent complexes in {[{LCuTb­(H2O)3}­{Fe­(CN)6}]·4H2O} n , or (ii) the CuII ions of adjacent complexes in {[CuII(Me 2 valpn)]2Dy­(H2O)­Fe­(CN)6·5.5H2O·2.5CH3CN} n . In contrast, 4 of the 22 discrete examples display SMM behavior. All four are tetrametallic 3d–4f complexes featuring a single [(Tp*)­FeIII(CN)3] moiety coordinated to a CuII ion: [(Tp*)­FeIII(CN)3CuII(L)­LnIII(NO3)3(H2O)3]­[(Tp*)­FeIII(CN)3]·2MeOH·5H2O, where Ln = Tb or Dy and L = (R,R)- or (S,S)-3-MeO-salcy (type 2 in ).

elements.content: Here, we report that tuning the reagent ratio and crystallization conditions employed for reactions of the macrocyclic SMM {CuII 3Tb}3+ building block 1 with a [M­(CN)6]3– linker (M = FeIII, CrIII, and CoIII), by employing different combinations of water with methanol, acetonitrile or dimethylformamide (DMF), permits the formation of five different 0D and 1D coordination assemblies, all of which feature identical 1:1 macrocycle:linker ratios, but differ in structure and magnetic properties.

elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

All seven complexes (2-8) were obtained as single crystals (see Table S4 in the Supporting Information) by layering solutions of the two reagents, the SMM building block 1 and selected hexacyanometallate linker, on each other and allowing them to diffuse together over a period of weeks to months.

elements.content: Depending on the solvent and the reaction conditions used (), the reaction of [Cu3Tb­(L Pr )­(NO3)2(H2O)]­NO3 (1) with excess K3[Fe­(CN)6] results in five different compounds, which fall into four distinctly different structural types: cocrystallized salt (type 1), discrete assemblies including a monomeric linker-coordinated macrocycle (type 2) and a dimer of macrocycles bridged by two linkers (type 3), and finally 1D chains (coordination polymers, type 4; see ). All five compounds have the same molecular ratio of one macrocycle per one molecule of the iron­(III) hexacyanide linker, largely because of the match of tricationic macrocyclic complex to trianionic linker, but they differ in structural type and solvent content.

All five compounds have the same molecular ratio of one macrocycle per one molecule of the iron(III) hexacyanide linker, largely because of the match of tricationic macrocyclic complex to trianionic linker, but they differ in structural type and solvent content.

Compounds 2–8 all contain 1:1 SMM:linker.

The fourth structural type, 1D chains (, bottom), consists of two different ferricyanide linker binding modes: one in which the linker bridges via cis cyanide groups, {[Cu3Tb­(L Pr )cis-Fe­(CN)6(H2O)3(MeOH)]·(H2O)3.75·(MeOH)0.75} n (5), whereas, in the other, it bridges via trans cyanide groups, {[Cu3Tb­(L Pr )trans-Fe­(CN)6(H2O)4]·(H2O)5·(DMF)5]} n (6). Note that 6 has only been synthesized twice, and that the crystals took several months to grow. Several attempts have been made to use other hexacyanide complexes as linkers, but only two compounds have crystallized. The first compound, {[Cu3Tb­(L Pr )­Cr­(CN)6(H2O)4]·(H2O)2.75}2 (7), is a type-3 dimer obtained with K3[Cr­(CN)6] as linkers. It is isostructural with 4. The second compound, {[Cu3Tb­(L Pr )­Co­(CN)6(H2O)3(MeOH)]·(H2O)4 ·(MeOH)} n (8), a chain, is obtained with K3[Co­(CN)6] as the linker. It is isomorphous to 5.

elements.content: For all structures 2–8, the macrocycle adopts a slightly curved conformation, coordinating one TbIII in the O6 pocket and three CuII in the N2O2 sites. The TbIII ion is coordinated by nine oxygen atoms, six being from the macrocycle, three being from water molecules, giving a tricapped trigonal prismatic geometry. The CuII ion possesses a square-pyramidal geometry in all cases, except for one Cu center, in 6, being square-planar. In all cases, the MIII metal ion in the hexacyanide linker (M = Fe, Cr, or Co) possesses an octahedral geometry.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystal Structures

For all structures 2-8, the macrocycle adopts a slightly curved conformation, coordinating one TbIII in the O6 pocket and three CuII in the N2O2 sites. The TbIII ion is coordinated by nine oxygen atoms, six being from the macrocycle, three being from water molecules, giving a tricapped trigonal prismatic geometry. The CuII ion possesses a square-pyramidal geometry in all cases, except for one Cu center, in 6, being square-planar. In all cases, the MIII metal ion in the hexacyanide linker (M = Fe, Cr, or Co) possesses an octahedral geometry.

elements.content: Single crystals of {[Cu3Tb­(L Pr )­(H2O)5]­[Fe­(CN)6]·(H2O)3·(MeCN)]} (2) suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained by slow liquid–liquid diffusion of a 19:1 ratio of the two reagents, K3[Fe­(CN)6] and 1, in a mixture of H2O/MeCN. The structure determination confirmed that there is no link between the macrocycle and the ferricyanide, so the result is the formation of a salt (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). All three CuII ions possess a square-pyramidal geometry with a long apical bond to a water molecule, and all three are almost perfectly regular square pyramids (trigonality factor τ < 0.06; see , as well as Table S5 in the Supporting Information).

Single crystals of [Cu3Tb(L  Pr )Fe(CN)6(H2O)4(MeCN)]⋅(H2O)2⋅(MeCN) (3) suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained by slow liquid-liquid diffusion of a 1.6:1 ratio of the two reagents, K3[Fe(CN)6] and 1, in a mixture of H2O/MeCN.

elements.content: The structure determination reveals the formation of a discrete monomer made of one ferricyanide and one macrocycle (1), forming a discrete anion–cation coordinated pair (3) where the ferricyanide is linked to the macrocycle via a cyanide nitrogen donor (see and Figures S2 and S3 in the Supporting Information). The three CuII ions bind one additional donor from either a cyanide nitrogen donor from the linker (Cu1) or a solvent molecule (Cu2 and Cu3) and possess a square-pyramidal geometry with a long apical bond (see and Table S5). One CuII is almost perfectly regular square pyramid (trigonality factor of τCu2 < 0.03) binding an acetonitrile molecule (Cu2–N = 2.742 Å).

elements.content: Single crystals of {[Cu3Tb­(L Pr )­Fe­(CN)6(H2O)4]·(H2O)6.75}2 (4) suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained by slow liquid–liquid diffusion of a 17:1 ratio of the two reagents, K3[Fe­(CN)6] and 1, in a mixture of H2O/MeCN. The structure determination revealed the formation of a discrete assembly made of two ferricyanide and two macrocycles (), with only half of hexacyanide and half macrocycle in the asymmetric unit, and the remainder of the complex generated by rotation about a 2-fold axis that runs through Fe(1) and Fe­(1a).

elements.content: Each iron­(III) hexacyanide linker bridges two macrocycles (1) via cis-cyanide groups coordinated to two different copper­(II) centers (angle Cu–Fe–Cu 105.56°) giving a dimer arrangement (see , as well as Figures S4 and S5 in the Supporting Information). Two of the three CuII ions are structurally identical and bind a cyanide nitrogen donor from the hexacyanide linker (Cu2 and Cu3), the third one (Cu1) binding a solvent molecule. All three CuII are perfectly regular square pyramids (trigonality factor of τ < 0.01). Classical hydrogen-bond interactions give a close 3D packing of hydrogen-bonded dimers via cyanide and water molecules (O12d···O34d = 2.977 Å, N53c···O34d = 2.965 Å, O38c···O13a′ = 2.540 Å, and N51c···O38c = 2.814 Å; see Figures S4 and S5). The Tb–Tb intradimer separation (7.405 Å) is far shorter than the intermolecular one (10.347 Å). In contrast, the intermolecular Cu–Cu separation (4.789 Å) is far shorter than intradimer one (7.178 Å), and also shorter than that observed within the macrocycle (6.137 Å; see , as well as Table S5).

elements.content: The three CuII ions bind one additional donor from either a cyanide nitrogen donor from the linker (Cu1 and Cu3) or a solvent molecule (Cu2), and possess a square-pyramidal geometry with a long apical bond. All three CuII are almost perfectly regular square pyramids (trigonality factor of τ < 0.1 for 5 and 8), one of them bonded to a methanol molecule (Cu2–O = 2.407 Å for 5 and 2.397 Å for 8), the other two bonded to the iron­(III) hexacyanide complex through the N atom of the cyanide ligand (Cu1–N = 2.290 Å and Cu3–N = 2.312 Å for 5, Cu1–N = 2.324 Å and Cu3–N = 2.295 Å for 8). Two macrocycles are bonded through two adjacent cyanide ligands in a cis-fashion (angle Cu–Fe–Cu = 90.24° for 5 and 8), giving a perpendicular arrangement of the macrocycles (see Figures S6–S9 and S12). Classical hydrogen-bond interactions and π–π interactions give a close three-dimensional (3D) packing of chains via weak π–π interactions (centroid to centroid distance = 3.566 Å) and hydrogen bonds between cyanides and water molecules (O10b-70a = 2.741 Å, O70a-63a = 2.701 Å, N52a-O63a = 2.815 Å, N54e-O63a = 2.981 Å, O61a-O11a = 2.789 Å, and N51a-O61a = 2.965 Å; see Figures S7 and S12 in the Supporting Information) for 5. The interchain Tb–Tb separation (8.416 Å for 5, 8.419 Å for 8) is far shorter than intrachain distance (12.713 Å for 5, 12.755 Å for 8). Similarly, the interchain Cu–Cu separation (6.128 Å for 5, 6.162 Å for 8) is shorter than intrachain ones (7.529 Å for 5, 7.533 Å for 8), and in the same range as the one observed within the macrocycle (6.142 Å for 5, 6.156 Å for 8; see , as well as Table S5).

elements.content: Single crystals of {[Cu3Tb­(L Pr )­Fe­(CN)6(H2O)4]·(H2O)5·(DMF)5]} n (6) suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained by slow diffusion of a 1.2:1 ratio of K3[Fe­(CN)6] and 1 in a H2O/DMF mixture. The structure determination confirmed the formation of a 1D coordination polymer, in which each iron­(III) hexacyanide linker binds one macrocycle (1) in a trans-fashion (see , as well as Figures S6, S10, and S13 in the Supporting Information). The asymmetric unit comprises one macrocycle and two halves of ferricyanide complexes, as they are crystallographically distinct. Two of the CuII bonded to the iron­(III) hexacyanide complex through the N atom of the cyanide ligand (Cu1–N = 2.298 Å and Cu3–N = 2.332 Å; see , as well as Table S5), one being an almost-perfectly regular square pyramid (trigonality factor of τCu3 < 0.03) and the other is slightly distorted toward trigonal bipyramidal (trigonality factor of τCu1 = 0.137). The third CuII possesses a square-planar geometry with a weak apical interaction with a water molecule (Cu2–O = 2.961 Å). Two adjacent macrocycles are bonded through one trans-cyanide ligands, to two different CuII centers (see Figures S7 and S10 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: Two different coordination modes can be distinguished due to the alternating orientations of the saddle-shaped macrocyclic moieties. Although the ferricyanide linkers are crystallographically distinct, they are geometrically similar (angles Cu–Fe–Cu = 180°) giving a parallel arrangement of the macrocycles with the chains packing in a linear way. Again, the chains pack together via two classical hydrogen-bond interactions between a cyanide moiety and a coordinated water molecule on an adjacent chain, resulting in a supramolecular 2D sheet network of hydrogen-bonded chains (N52a-O40a = 2.836 Å, N57e-O40a = 2.814 Å, Figure S13 in the Supporting Information). These sheets interact by nonclassical hydrogen bonds between the same water molecule and phenyl ring from another chain (O40a-C12x = 3.177 Å) giving a 3D network overall. The Tb–Tb interchain separation (9.836 Å) is far shorter than the intrachain one (14.463 Å). Similarly, the Cu–Cu interchain separation (7.696 Å) is shorter than the intrachain distance (10.202 Å), but is longer than that observed within the macrocycle (6.123 Å; see and Table S5).

elements.content: Single crystals of {[Cu3Tb­(L Pr )­Cr­(CN)6(H2O)4]·(H2O)2.75}2 (7) suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained by slow liquid–liquid diffusion of a 3.3:1 ratio of the two reagents, K3[Cr­(CN)6] and 1, in a mixture of H2O/MeCN. The structure determination (Figure S11 in the Supporting Information) revealed a molecular complex made of two ferricyanide and two macrocycles, forming a discrete dimer isostructural to 4 (type 3), although in 7, the asymmetric unit is different and comprises one hexacyanide complex and one macrocycle. Each chromium­(III) hexacyanide linker bridges two macrocycles (1) via cis-cyanide groups coordinated to two different CuII centers (∠Cu–Cr–Cu = 105.38°), giving a dimer arrangement similar to 4. The three CuII ions bind one additional donor from either a cyanide nitrogen donor from the linker (Cu1 and Cu2) or a solvent molecule (Cu3) and possess a square-pyramidal geometry with a long apical bond. One CuII is a perfectly regular square pyramid (trigonality factor of τCu2 < 0.01) being bonded to the iron­(III) hexacyanide complex through the cyanide N atom (Cu2–N = 2.412 Å).

elements.content: Black crystals of 2, 3, 4, and 7, brown crystals of 5, and yellow crystals of 8 were reproducibly synthesized. The small scale reaction that produced a small quantity of crystals of 6 over a period of six months failed to scale up, but was satisfactorily reproduced on a small scale, allowing microanalysis and IR measurements to be done. It is important to note that, in all cases, 1–8, the architectures obtained () contain a 1:1 ratio of linker X to 1, despite the reaction ratio employed varying from 1.3:1 to 19:1 ().
elements.clean_text:
Summary of Structural Outcomes

Black crystals of 2, 3, 4, and 7, brown crystals of 5, and yellow crystals of 8 were reproducibly synthesized. The small scale reaction that produced a small quantity of crystals of 6 over a period of six months failed to scale up, but was satisfactorily reproduced on a small scale, allowing microanalysis and IR measurements to be done. It is important to note that, in all cases, 1-8, the architectures obtained () contain a 1:1 ratio of linker X to 1, despite the reaction ratio employed varying from 1.3:1 to 19:1 ().

elements.content: Chains formed in cases where the [CuII 3TbIII(L Pr )]:hexacyanometallate ratio was close to stoichiometric, i.e., 1:1, but, interestingly, the outcomes of these reactions were also solvent dependent: reactions involving [CuII 3TbIII(L Pr )] and a slight excess (1.2–1.6 equiv) of K3[FeIII(CN)6], gave a monomer (1) when aqueous MeCN was used, whereas chains (5 and 6) were obtained from aqueous MeOH or DMF (). In contrast, when a large excess of linker was employed in aqueous MeCN either a salt (1) or a dimer (3) resulted, depending on which solution was layered on top ().

elements.content: For the other hexacyanide linkers, only two of the crystallization attempts, both conducted in aqueous MeOH, produced single crystals. Specifically, a large excess of the Cr­(III) linker gave a type-3 dimer (7) whereas a slight excess of the Co­(III) linker resulted in a chain (8). Note that, for both Cr­(III) and Co­(III), attempts in aqueous MeCN led to the same results.

elements.content: Both of the related literature SCMs ( and , as well as Tables S2 and S6), are chains of general type 4 structure (). One, [{LCuTb­(H2O)3}­{Fe­(CN)6}]·4H2O, features both cis- and trans-bridging between the CuII and TbIII ions, but not bridging between two CuII ions, as is observed in the present type 4 compounds (5, 6, and 8). In contrast, the other reported SCM, {[CuII(Me 2 valpn)]2Dy­(H2O)­Fe­(CN)6·5.5H2O·2.5CH3CN} n , features only trans-bridging, and only between two CuII ions, so it is most similar to our chain complex 6. Although there are only two claimed SCM systems reported in the literature, it appears that SCM behavior might be observed for systems featuring (a) cis- and/or trans-bridging between (b) either the CuII and LnIII ions, or between the CuII ions. Comparing the structural parameters of these two reported systems (Table S6) with our chain compounds 5, 6, and 8, the most noticeable difference is that the published SCMs have larger interchain metal–metal distances, while the intrachain metal–metal distances are quite similar. The Cu–NC angles for the reported SCMs (142.2°–152.0°) are in a somewhat narrower range than for the analogous angles seen in 5, 6, and 8 (134.5°–176.9°). Interestingly, in 6, which does not show any slow relaxation of magnetization, the Fe–Cu–Fe angle (180.0°) is appreciably wider than in the SCM {[CuII(Me 2 valpn)]2Dy­(H2O) Fe­(CN)6·5.5H2O·2.5CH3CN} n (162.6°).

The numbers of SCM/SMM are zero unless noted in brackets.

The four reported SMMs based on similar systems ( and , as well as Tables S2 and S7), general formula [(Tp*)­FeIII(CN)3CuII((R,R)-3-MeO-salcy)­LnIII(NO3)3(H2O)3]­[(Tp*)­FeIII(CN)3]·2MeOH·5H2O (L = (R,R)-3-MeO-salcy or (S,S)-3-MeO-salcy, Ln = Tb or Dy), are all ionic complexes of type 1 (). In comparison to 2–4, which are also nonpolymeric systems but do not display any slow relaxation of magnetization, the intermolecular CuII–CuII distances are shorter in 2–4 (4.79–6.60 Å) than the reported SMMs (9.21–9.35 Å), while the intermolecular TbIII–TbIII distances are very similar. Again, the Cu–NC angles of the reported SMMs (132.5°–134.2°) fall in a narrower range than in the complexes reported herein (3 and 4; 137.0°–169.3°).

elements.content: In summary, while all seven complexes, 2–8, contain a 1:1 ratio of building block to linker, despite the various reagent ratios employed, probably in large part due to this providing perfect charge balance (3+ block with 3– linker), it appears that the use of a close to stoichiometric ratio of these two components, and the use of aqueous MeOH as the solvent, promotes the formation of 1D chains, whereas the use of a larger excess of linker promotes the formation of discrete complexes.

elements.content: At room temperature, the χT products (normalized for one [CuII 3TbIII(L Pr )] and one hexacyanometallate unit) for 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 are 13.7, 13.9, 13.8, 13.9, and 13.8 cm3 K mol–1, all of which are in reasonable agreement with the expected value (13.7 cm3 K mol–1) for three Cu­(II) (S = 1/2; g = 2.2; C = 0.45 cm3 K mol–1) ions, one Fe­(III) (S = 1/2; g = 2.4; C = 0.54 cm3 K mol–1) ion and one Tb­(III) (S = 3, L = 3, 7F6, g = 3/2, C = 11.815 cm3 K mol–1) ion (see , as well as Figures S14–S18 in the Supporting Information). The χT value at 300 K for the Cr­(III) hexacyanide linked type-3 dimer 7 is 16.3 cm3 K mol–1, which is slightly higher than the expected value of 15.0 cm3 K mol–1 (Cr­(III) S = 3/2; g = 2.0; C = 1.875 cm3 K mol–1; see , as well as Figure S19 in the Supporting Information). The χT product for 8, the Co­(III) hexacyanide linked cis-chain, 12.7 cm3 K mol–1 at room temperature (RT), is in good agreement with the expected value of 13.2 cm3 K mol–1 (Co­(III) being diamagnetic; and Figure S20 in the Supporting Information).

Magnetic Characterization

At room temperature, the χT products (normalized for one [CuII 3TbIII(L  Pr )] and one hexacyanometallate unit) for 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 are 13.7, 13.9, 13.8, 13.9, and 13.8 cm3 K mol-1, all of which are in reasonable agreement with the expected value (13.7 cm3 K mol-1) for three Cu(II) (S = 1/2; g = 2.2; C = 0.45 cm3 K mol-1) ions, one Fe(III) (S = 1/2; g = 2.4; C = 0.54 cm3 K mol-1) ion and one Tb(III) (S = 3, L = 3, 7F6, g = 3/2, C = 11.815 cm3 K mol-1) ion (see , as well as Figures S14-S18 in the Supporting Information). The χT value at 300 K for the Cr(III) hexacyanide linked type-3 dimer 7 is 16.3 cm3 K mol-1, which is slightly higher than the expected value of 15.0 cm3 K mol-1 (Cr(III) S = 3/2; g = 2.0; C = 1.875 cm3 K mol-1; see , as well as Figure S19 in the Supporting Information). The χT product for 8, the Co(III) hexacyanide linked cis-chain, 12.7 cm3 K mol-1 at room temperature (RT), is in good agreement with the expected value of 13.2 cm3 K mol-1 (Co(III) being diamagnetic;  and Figure S20 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: As shown in (also see Figures S14–18), the temperature dependence of the χT product for 2 (type-1 salt), 3 (monomer; type-2 complex), 4 (type-3 dimer), and 5 (type-4 cis-1D-chain) is very similar and resembles that of the parent building block, 1. As the temperature is lowered for 2, 3, 4, and 5, χT exhibits an increase to a maximum at 3.5, 6.0, 5.5, and 9.0 K, respectively, as expected in the presence of dominating ferromagnetic interactions between the Cu­(II) and Tb­(III) metal ions in the [CuII 3TbL Pr ]3– building block, as was previously observed for 1. Further lowering the temperature to the limit of the measurement (1.85 K) results in a slight decrease in the χT product for 2, 3, 4, and 5, probably because of the Tb­(III) magnetic anisotropy and/or potentially weak antiferromagnetic interactions between building blocks and/or between coordination assemblies. In contrast, in the case of 6 (type 4 trans-1D-chain), lowering the temperature causes a steady increase of χT right through to 1.85 K, with no decrease at very low temperatures.
elements.clean_text: As shown in  (also see Figures S14-18), the temperature dependence of the χT product for 2 (type-1 salt), 3 (monomer; type-2 complex), 4 (type-3 dimer), and 5 (type-4 cis-1D-chain) is very similar and resembles that of the parent building block, 1. As the temperature is lowered for 2, 3, 4, and 5, χT exhibits an increase to a maximum at 3.5, 6.0, 5.5, and 9.0 K, respectively, as expected in the presence of dominating ferromagnetic interactions between the Cu(II) and Tb(III) metal ions in the [CuII 3TbL  Pr ]3- building block, as was previously observed for 1. Further lowering the temperature to the limit of the measurement (1.85 K) results in a slight decrease in the χT product for 2, 3, 4, and 5, probably because of the Tb(III) magnetic anisotropy and/or potentially weak antiferromagnetic interactions between building blocks and/or between coordination assemblies. In contrast, in the case of 6 (type 4 trans-1D-chain), lowering the temperature causes a steady increase of χT right through to 1.85 K, with no decrease at very low temperatures.

elements.content: The nature of the Cu­(II)–Fe­(III) interaction is expected to have a significant influence of the magnetic behavior of these systems, so this was probed by comparing the temperature dependence of the χT product for 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7 with appropriate analogues (Figures S15–S20). In a previous report, a similar analysis was performed to determine that the Cu­(II)–Cu­(II) and Cu­(II)–Tb­(III) interactions are ferromagnetic in 1. Specifically, subtracting the experimental data for 2 (type-1 salt) from that of 3 (type-2 monomer) removes the inherent paramagnetism of the Cu­(II), Fe­(III), and Tb­(III) ions, as well as the effect of the Cu­(II)–Cu­(II) and Cu­(II)–Tb­(III) interactions from the [CuII 3TbL Pr ]3– building block. In the resulting difference plot (ΔχT vs T; Figure S15), ΔχT increases with decreasing temperature, to a maximum at ∼11.5 K. Taking the hypothesis that all the other magnetic characteristics of the constituents do not change between 2 and 3, it strongly suggests that the Cu­(II)–Fe­(III) interaction is of ferromagnetic nature in 3. The decrease in the difference plot at still lower temperatures is thought to be due to an antiferromagnetic intermolecular interaction, given that the effect of the anisotropy of the Tb­(III) ion, which can cause a decrease in χT with decreasing temperature, has already been excluded from ΔχT by this method. In the same fashion, subtracting the temperature dependence of the χT product for 2 (type-1 salt) from that of 4 (type-3 dimer), 5 (type-4 cis-1d-chain), or 6 (type-4 trans-1D-chain), leaves only the nature of the Cu­(II)–Fe­(III) interaction (see Figures S16–S18). In the case of 4, 5, and 6, the Cu­(II)–Fe­(III) interaction seems to be extremely small, as the χT product shows no marked temperature dependence above 50 K, below which weak antiferromagnetic (for 4 and 5) or ferromagnetic (for 6) intermolecular interactions might cause a decrease or increase, respectively. For the Cr­(III) hexacyanide linked type-3 dimer, 7, subtracting the data for 1 (the SMM [CuII 3TbL Pr ]3– building block) yields a difference plot with a gradual increase in ΔχT upon cooling, down to a maximum at ∼6.6 K. With the same hypothesis as above, this result suggests a weak ferromagnetic Cu­(II)–Cr­(III) interaction (see Figure S19). A small decrease in ΔχT below 6.6 K down to 1.85 K most likely reveals the presence of weak antiferromagnetic intermolecular interactions. The same analysis for 8, in which the [CuII 3TbL Pr ]3– building block are linked by diamagnetic Co­(III) hexacyanide along the chain, reveals only extremely weak antiferromagnetic interactions between magnetic tetranuclear complexes (see Figure S20).

In the same fashion, subtracting the temperature dependence of the χT product for 2 (type-1 salt) from that of 4 (type-3 dimer), 5 (type-4 cis-1d-chain), or 6 (type-4 trans-1D-chain), leaves only the nature of the Cu(II)-Fe(III) interaction (see Figures S16-S18). In the case of 4, 5, and 6, the Cu(II)-Fe(III) interaction seems to be extremely small, as the χT product shows no marked temperature dependence above 50 K, below which weak antiferromagnetic (for 4 and 5) or ferromagnetic (for 6) intermolecular interactions might cause a decrease or increase, respectively. elements.content: To check for the presence of magnetic hysteresis, the field dependence of magnetization was measured for all of the compounds (see Figures S21–S27 in the Supporting Information). None show any hysteretic behavior, suggesting that the possible SMM properties of these systems induced by the presence of [CuII 3TbL Pr ]3– units are certainly observable only below 1.85 K. The presence of magnetic anisotropy was systematically detected from the field dependence of reduced magnetization: the resulting curves are not superimposable, as expected in the presence of the pronounced magnetic anisotropy arising from the Tb­(III) ion.

elements.content: In the case of the Cr­(III) hexacyanide linked type-3 dimer (7), the field dependence of the magnetization at 1.8 K exhibits an “S”-shaped curve, with an inflection point at H C = 1800 Oe (see the left portion of ) that reveals the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions compensated by the applied magnetic field at H C. This characteristic field has been followed as a function of the temperature using combined χ vs T and dM/dH vs H data (). As H C extrapolates well to zero at a finite temperature, this approach allows the determination of the (T, H) magnetic phase diagram for 7 (see the bottom right portion of ). The obtained phase diagram is typical of metamagnetic behavior with the presence of a 3D antiferromagnetic ordered state below T N = 2.3 K and only an antiferromagnetic–paramagnetic phase transition line (H C(T)).

elements.content: The dynamics of the magnetization was evaluated by ac susceptibility measurements for all of the compounds. For 2–7, there is a complete absence of an out-of-phase over the top of it to (χ̋) signal above 1.8 K, indicating that these compounds do not display any sign of SMM properties using our available set of dc and ac techniques (see Figure S28 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: In contrast, in the case of the Co­(III) hexacyanide linked trans-chain 8, clear nonzero χ″ component is observed below 2.8 K in zero-dc field (see , as well as Figure S29 in the Supporting Information), which is comparable with that observed for the SMM 1. This slow relaxation of the magnetization was studied as a function of the temperature below 6 K and at ac frequencies between 1 Hz and 1500 Hz. Unfortunately, in zero-dc field (), no clear maximum of the χ″ vs T or χ″ vs ν is observed, so it is not possible to experimentally quantify the characteristic relaxation time of the magnetization. Therefore, the slow dynamics were studied in the presence of a small dc field (Figure S29). However, these measurements do not lead to a significant shift of the ac signal in the experimental frequency window, so again the maximum of the χ″ signal is not observed. Given that the ac behavior of 8 is so similar to that of the parent SMM 1, it seems, as expected, that the magnetism of 8 is governed by the magnetic behavior of the individual [CuIITbIII(L Pr )]3+ subunits.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have successfully prepared single crystals of seven different complexes (2–8) from the [CuII 3TbIII(L Pr )]3+ macrocyclic SMM building block in combination with three different hexacyanide linkers, [MIII(CN)6]3–, where M = Fe, Cr, or Co, by using a variety of crystallization conditions. Despite employing a range of building block:linker reaction ratios, all seven crystallographically characterized products feature a 1:1 ratio of building blocks to linkers, thanks in large part to the fact that these moieties have been chosen to have perfectly matched charges, −3 and +3, respectively. The different structural motifs result in differing magnetic behavior: although none of the [FeIII(CN)6]3– complexes (2, 3, 4, 5, 6) exhibit SMM or SCM behavior, the [CrIII(CN)6]3– type-3 dimer (7) shows a metamagnetic behavior, and the [CoIII(CN)6]3– type-4 1D-chain (8) shows slow relaxation of the magnetization associated with the isolated [Cu3Tb­(L Pr )]3+ units.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, we have successfully prepared single crystals of seven different complexes (2-8) from the [CuII 3TbIII(L  Pr )]3+ macrocyclic SMM building block in combination with three different hexacyanide linkers, [MIII(CN)6]3-, where M = Fe, Cr, or Co, by using a variety of crystallization conditions. Despite employing a range of building block:linker reaction ratios, all seven crystallographically characterized products feature a 1:1 ratio of building blocks to linkers, thanks in large part to the fact that these moieties have been chosen to have perfectly matched charges, -3 and +3, respectively. The different structural motifs result in differing magnetic behavior: although none of the [FeIII(CN)6]3- complexes (2, 3, 4, 5, 6) exhibit SMM or SCM behavior, the [CrIII(CN)6]3- type-3 dimer (7) shows a metamagnetic behavior, and the [CoIII(CN)6]3- type-4 1D-chain (8) shows slow relaxation of the magnetization associated with the isolated [Cu3Tb(L  Pr )]3+ units.

elements.content: These results show that the magnetic information is not being communicated efficiently enough between the [Cu3Tb­(L Pr )]3+ units, along these one-dimensional coordination networks, to obtain single-chain magnet (SCM) properties. Given that the octacyanide linker also failed to achieve this, our current efforts are directed toward obtaining systems with enhanced linker-macrocycle magnetic interactions, by choosing (a) a better [M3Ln­(L)]3+ building block, one in which M is chosen so that the magnetic orbitals of M are at right angles to the macrocycle, thereby facilitating overlap with the linker and, hence, magnetic exchange; and (b) a more appropriate linker, specifically one that links the anisotropic lanthanide ions, rather than the transition-metal ions as the cyanide linkers have a tendency to do, and is bulky enough to help separate the chains more efficiently and negate interchain interactions. Work is in progress pursuing these possibilities.
elements.clean_text: These results show that the magnetic information is not being communicated efficiently enough between the [Cu3Tb(L  Pr )]3+ units, along these one-dimensional coordination networks, to obtain single-chain magnet (SCM) properties. Given that the octacyanide linker also failed to achieve this, our current efforts are directed toward obtaining systems with enhanced linker-macrocycle magnetic interactions, by choosing (a) a better [M3Ln(L)]3+ building block, one in which M is chosen so that the magnetic orbitals of M are at right angles to the macrocycle, thereby facilitating overlap with the linker and, hence, magnetic exchange; and (b) a more appropriate linker, specifically one that links the anisotropic lanthanide ions, rather than the transition-metal ions as the cyanide linkers have a tendency to do, and is bulky enough to help separate the chains more efficiently and negate interchain interactions. Work is in progress pursuing these possibilities.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray structure determinations were performed on all of the complexes, 2–8 (see Table S4 in the Supporting Information). Data were collected at 89 K on a Bruker SMART Apex diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Structure solution and full-matrix least-squares refinement were performed using the SHELXTL software package. H atoms bonded to C atoms were placed in calculated positions and rode on the attached C atom, while those on O atoms were placed in calculated positions that gave the best hydrogen bonds and then the coordinates were fixed. In all cases, U(H) = 1.2 U(O). In 3, 5, 6, and 8, no disorder was encountered and all non-H atoms were refined anisotropically. For 4, all non-H atoms were refined anisotropically in the main residue, whereas some of the solvent molecules were disordered and refined isotropically. For 2 and 7, no disorder was encountered in the main residue but some atoms had to be refined isotropically; some of the solvent molecules were disordered and refined isotropically. For further details, see the cif files (CCDC 1024871–1024877).
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structure Determinations

Single-crystal X-ray structure determinations were performed on all of the complexes, 2-8 (see Table S4 in the Supporting Information). Data were collected at 89 K on a Bruker SMART Apex diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Structure solution and full-matrix least-squares refinement were performed using the SHELXTL software package. H atoms bonded to C atoms were placed in calculated positions and rode on the attached C atom, while those on O atoms were placed in calculated positions that gave the best hydrogen bonds and then the coordinates were fixed. In all cases, U(H) = 1.2 U(O). In 3, 5, 6, and 8, no disorder was encountered and all non-H atoms were refined anisotropically. For 4, all non-H atoms were refined anisotropically in the main residue, whereas some of the solvent molecules were disordered and refined isotropically. For 2 and 7, no disorder was encountered in the main residue but some atoms had to be refined isotropically; some of the solvent molecules were disordered and refined isotropically. For further details, see the cif files (CCDC 1024871-1024877).

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed using an MPMS-XL Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer operating between 1.8 K and 300 K for dc applied fields ranging from −7 T to 7 T at ∼100–400 Oe min–1 for H < 1 T and 500–2500 Oe min–1 for H > 1 T. ac susceptibility experiments were realized at ac frequencies ranging from 1 Hz to 1500 Hz with an ac field amplitude of 3 Oe. Measurements were performed on analytically pure polycrystalline samples [7.94 mg (2), 8.19 mg (4), 10.40 mg (5), 0.76 mg (6), 8.29 mg (7), 13.56 mg (8)], which were loaded into a sealed polyethylene bag (3 cm × 0.5 cm × 0.02 cm, 26.56 mg (2), 33.28 mg (4), 23.14 mg (5), 25.26 mg (6), 26.68 mg (7), 27.45 mg (8)). Alternatively, the sample [11.43 mg (3), 28.10 mg (4)] was measured in its mother liquor [22.31 mg (3), 36.50 mg (4)] in a sealed straw under argon. In this latter case, the sample was measured covered and thus restrained in a minimum of their frozen mother liquor within a sealed straw to prevent desolvation/degradation of the solid. No evaporation of the mother liquor was observed during the measurements. The mass of the sample was determined after the measurements and subsequent mother liquor evaporation. The magnetic data were corrected for the sample holder and the diamagnetic contributions.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed using an MPMS-XL Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer operating between 1.8 K and 300 K for dc applied fields ranging from -7 T to 7 T at ~100-400 Oe min-1 for H < 1 T and 500-2500 Oe min-1 for H > 1 T. ac susceptibility experiments were realized at ac frequencies ranging from 1 Hz to 1500 Hz with an ac field amplitude of 3 Oe. Measurements were performed on analytically pure polycrystalline samples [7.94 mg (2), 8.19 mg (4), 10.40 mg (5), 0.76 mg (6), 8.29 mg (7), 13.56 mg (8)], which were loaded into a sealed polyethylene bag (3 cm × 0.5 cm × 0.02 cm, 26.56 mg (2), 33.28 mg (4), 23.14 mg (5), 25.26 mg (6), 26.68 mg (7), 27.45 mg (8)). Alternatively, the sample [11.43 mg (3), 28.10 mg (4)] was measured in its mother liquor [22.31 mg (3), 36.50 mg (4)] in a sealed straw under argon. In this latter case, the sample was measured covered and thus restrained in a minimum of their frozen mother liquor within a sealed straw to prevent desolvation/degradation of the solid. No evaporation of the mother liquor was observed during the measurements. The mass of the sample was determined after the measurements and subsequent mother liquor evaporation. The magnetic data were corrected for the sample holder and the diamagnetic contributions.

cln_elements.content: At room temperature, the χT products (normalized for one [CuII 3TbIII(L Pr )] and one hexacyanometallate unit) for 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 are 13.7, 13.9, 13.8, 13.9, and 13.8 cm3 K mol–1, all of which are in reasonable agreement with the expected value (13.7 cm3 K mol–1) for three Cu­(II) (S = 1/2; g = 2.2; C = 0.45 cm3 K mol–1) ions, one Fe­(III) (S = 1/2; g = 2.4; C = 0.54 cm3 K mol–1) ion and one Tb­(III) (S = 3, L = 3, 7F6, g = 3/2, C = 11.815 cm3 K mol–1) ion (see , as well as Figures S14–S18 in the Supporting Information). The χT value at 300 K for the Cr­(III) hexacyanide linked type-3 dimer 7 is 16.3 cm3 K mol–1, which is slightly higher than the expected value of 15.0 cm3 K mol–1 (Cr­(III) S = 3/2; g = 2.0; C = 1.875 cm3 K mol–1; see , as well as Figure S19 in the Supporting Information). The χT product for 8, the Co­(III) hexacyanide linked cis-chain, 12.7 cm3 K mol–1 at room temperature (RT), is in good agreement with the expected value of 13.2 cm3 K mol–1 (Co­(III) being diamagnetic; and Figure S20 in the Supporting Information).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Characterization

At room temperature, the χT products (normalized for one [CuII 3TbIII(L  Pr )] and one hexacyanometallate unit) for 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 are 13.7, 13.9, 13.8, 13.9, and 13.8 cm3 K mol-1, all of which are in reasonable agreement with the expected value (13.7 cm3 K mol-1) for three Cu(II) (S = 1/2; g = 2.2; C = 0.45 cm3 K mol-1) ions, one Fe(III) (S = 1/2; g = 2.4; C = 0.54 cm3 K mol-1) ion and one Tb(III) (S = 3, L = 3, 7F6, g = 3/2, C = 11.815 cm3 K mol-1) ion (see , as well as Figures S14-S18 in the Supporting Information). The χT value at 300 K for the Cr(III) hexacyanide linked type-3 dimer 7 is 16.3 cm3 K mol-1, which is slightly higher than the expected value of 15.0 cm3 K mol-1 (Cr(III) S = 3/2; g = 2.0; C = 1.875 cm3 K mol-1; see , as well as Figure S19 in the Supporting Information). The χT product for 8, the Co(III) hexacyanide linked cis-chain, 12.7 cm3 K mol-1 at room temperature (RT), is in good agreement with the expected value of 13.2 cm3 K mol-1 (Co(III) being diamagnetic;  and Figure S20 in the Supporting Information).

cln_elements.content: Schematic view of the four structural types observed for the assembly of 1 with linking group X = [MIII(CN)6]3–, where MIII is Fe, Cr, or Co: a salt (top left), a monomer (top middle), a dimer of macrocycles bridged by two linkers (top right) and a 1D chain (bottom), all of which feature a 1:1 ratio of 1 to linker X, regardless of the ratio employed in the reaction.
